newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigerian democracy campaigner, unionist detained.
newsitem.headline: Nigerian democracy campaigner, unionist detained.

text.p: A Nigerian democracy campaigner and a trade unionist have been detained by security forces, a local human rights group said on Thursday.

"We call for the immediate and unconditional release of Mr Anselm Akele and Dr Frederick Fasehun who were illegally arrested on December 17 and 18, respectively," the Committee for the Defence of Human Rights (CDHR) group said in a statement.
It did not say why the two men were arrested and there has been no confirmation of the arrests by the authorities.
The independent Guardian reported on Thursday that Fasehun, a medical doctor, was taken away on Wednesday morning after a police search of his house and private hospital.
Fasehun took over as chairman of the umbrella Campaign for Democracy from Beko Ransome-Kuti who in 1995 was given a 15-year prison sentence for his part in an alleged coup plot.
Akele is chairman of a wing of a public workers' union.
Nigeria's commercial capital, Lagos, is in a state of high tension following two bomb explosions in less than a week which have seriously injured over a dozen soldiers.
Nobody has claimed responsibility for the attacks but police in November accused opponents of the military government of being behind a bungled car-bomb which killed the three would-be bombers.
CDHR condemned the bomb blasts but said only democracy could restore peace in the country.

"In so far as the military remains in stolen power, general insecurity, violence, crime, terrorism and political assasinations will continue in Nigeria," it said, adding that ... "enthronement of a genuine democratic setting is an imperative condition for the resuscitation of peace and tranquility."
Dozens of opposition figures are detained in Africa's most populous nation, which has become a pariah state for alleged human rights abuses and lack of democracy.
Among the detainees are Moshood Abiola, the presumed winner of a 1993 presidential poll, whose annulment plunged Nigeria into turmoil.
